subsection.title: Functions as Maps
subsection.p: When we first introduced functions, we thought of them as maps between two variables, x \overset{f}\mapsto y. We can visualize a function as a map by thinking of the domain and range as each belonging to one real number line. The function is a rule for a mapping arrow between those two number lines. For a value x in the domain, the arrow must point to a specific location on the y number line.

The next figure illustrates the identity function f(x)=x as a map. For every value x in the domain, the value of y is the same as x.
